"Beauty is in the eye of the beholder." If you've ever watched The Twilight Zone, you know what this statement means. And no, The Twilight Zone has nothing to do with the Twilight series. 
What this statement is implying is that YOU are the one who decides what is beautiful. The statement also branches off into implying a lot of other things like, "Who decides what is wrong and right?" Really, it's up to you. If you think incest is disgusting, then so be it. If you think killing a ton of bad guys with the Death Note is wrong, then that's according to yourown sense of justice. Really, this anime deals a lot with deep questions people have in their everyday lives. What is wrong, and what is right? I believe you decide that for yourself. If you believe that incest is wrong, then I suggest not watching the last 3 episodes. Other than those last 3 episodes, you're going to see some lovely romance as well as some nice sex scenes mixed in.


Yosuga no Sora starts off with us learning that a pair of twins are moving to the countryside after their parents death. Mind you, they'd lived there before. You learn that our Protagonist is "super cute" and all the girls fawn over him. Honestly, I like those kind of protagonists. However, what you expect when you have a protagonist like that is a harem. In this anime, that's not the case. Yosuga no Sora is in what's called a "multi-arc branching" format. What this means is that there are 4 arcs given to each of the main girl protagonists. After each ark you go back in time to before any romance has started and you switch girls. Each ark usually ends with a nice sex scene and a happy ending. In my opinion, the arks go from worst to best. Now if you don't like incest, this might might not be the case.


From what I've told you, you can already kind of expect what this anime is going to be like. 4 short little romances. Good romances, mind you. If you're into the romance genre and can handle a little soft sex scene here and there, Yosuga no Sora is the anime for you. Some people will be turned away by the multi-arc branching format, but this is still a great love story. A lot of romance anime have trouble with the ending, but Yosuga no Sora has a beautiful and tear-jerking ending. Give it a try!

This anime i will honestly say made me cry; Unlike most harems i watch this one is more... dramatic then most, there are of course comic reliifes through out the show. The story has a very heart hitting and sad plot, Again diffrent than other harems the exprision of who the guy is going for is very apparent. The anime is more like a game with diffrent senarios (which makes sense because they did make a game). Supriseingly, dispite the diffrence of this harem and the many others, this anime is the not only the best harem i have ever seen, but also the bestanime i have seen. The music i must say is the best part of the anime, also the story is just a masterpiece. Allthough there are R rated scenes, and many people may say that it is the worst and insest is a abomantion against nature, but i must disagree. Love is love, no matter what people think and this anime expresses that the most. This anime I will share with everyone mature enough and let them enjoy the love between a couple.

Let me start off with this statement: Don't let the incest stop you from watching this Anime.
Personally I was a little hesitant myself, but after finishing this series, I enjoyed it very much.
Story wise, I was pleasantly happy with. When two are in love, why should anything else stop them? It's the same that goes with gays/lesbians. Why can't they be together? Because society won't accept it? So their feelings must be constricted and covered by a blanket of lies in order for society to accept them? Haruka tried exactly that with Nao; trying change himself in order for society to accept him, but deepdown he knew he loved Sora.


The soundtrack was amazing, consisting of mainly piano pieces. The voice acting was also straight on. I really felt the emotions through them.


The art was also beautiful. The characters were drawn beautifully. The only real grip with me is that the nipples looked a little awkward for some reason. 


I loved the emotional states of each character and Haruka tends to them all.


Overall, I say watch it if you want a story that teaches about personal moral and how society affects one's love for another.

This is my first ever review, so it probably won't be amazing but here we go.
This is an anime that is overlooked by many people due to the fact that it contains incest and nudity. Sadly, many people pass this off as some "fetish hentai". Well, to put it simply, they could not be any more wrong. I admit that I had doubts for this anime, but by the end of it, I was extremely glad I watched all of it, one of the best decisions of my life and really opened my mind up.
This anime is based off the visual novel, which is AMAZING.Due to the limited amount of episodes, the anime simply doesn't match up to the VN, but it does it's best with what it has to work with. The anime definitely captured the dramatic yet beautiful nature of the VN.


It provided some pretty good character development despite the short number of episodes each character had for their "arc". Personally, my favourite arc has to be Sora's (both in the anime and the VN). The whole backstory of her bond with Haru almost makes me not see it as incest (I won't go into details though, as it can be spoilerish). On first impressions, she may come off as an ignorant bratty childish girl, but she is FAR from it. In fact, she's one of my favourite characters ever. The other characters are very likeable too, and have interesting backstories. 


The art is absolutely stunning, especially the character designs and scenery in general. The creators have done the best they can here to replicate the absolutely beautiful artwork of the VN.


The music is simply one of the most beautiful scores I have ever heard in anything. I'd even go as far as it so it surprassed the amazing music of the VN. Tracks like "Old Memory" and "Toui Sora He", despite being used repetitively, are absolutely amazing and really add to the beautiful and dramatic nature of this show. Furthermore, the voice acting was brilliant, Haru captured the gentle personality of himself from the VN, whilst Sora's captured the fragile personality of herself.


Very few anime have pulled my heart strings as much as this one, it's up there with Clannad AS and White Album 2 in terms of emotional impact, in my opinion. I've wrote this review simply to get off my chest how much this anime means to me, it will always have a special place in my heart, and it honestly saddens me to see it have such low ratings. My advice to anyone who may watch this: Open your mind and heart, and just see the scenes of sexual nature as a form of art and embrace it as part of the story. This is NOT a hentai, nor a typical ecchi anime, despite it having ecchi as a tag. 


Thank you for reading this, and I HIGHLY recommend checking the VN out (As of 23/05/2015, Sora and Kazuha's routes have been translated to English).

This review is late and way pass the airing date so I don't expect many people to turn to this. After going on anime hiatus for school work for a few months, I started only recently to catch up on things. After finishing Yosuga no Sora last night, I felt I was obligated to write a review for it. And rest assured, it is relatively unfair and impotent to compare this with... let's say Highschool of the Dead since they can't possibly be judged on the same basis, I will rate it on an impartial scale for romance/harem types.
Yosuga no Sora is an anime basedoff a h- game. The anime is "autobussed" which means that the episodes are divided so each female protagonist gets their own arc. Now at this stage I'm convinced half of the people reading this review who haven't watched it yet are going to stop reading and not watch this simply because it's "another one of those cheap knock-off harem animes based off some game that no one's heard about". I suppose it wouldn't really matter if I told those people that what they think can't possibly be any further than the truth. Yes Yosuga no Sora is based off something, but that doesn't diminish the value of it. I found the story very detailed, thought out and with massive amounts of emphasize on questioning human morality and feelings. I hate lovey mushy crap relationship animes, but even so, the exquisite nature which this anime was presented left me speechless when the last moments of episode 12 ticked away. 


Story (9/10)

Yosuga no Sora starts with two twins, Haruto and Sora riding a silent train back to a rural town. After the death of their parents in a car accident, Haru, the older brother, in order to care for his fragile little sister, Sora, decides it would be best for them to move back to the town where their grandparents lived, where they experienced so many reminiscent childhood memories hidden away in their conscience. After introducing the female characters, all of who are Haruto's classmates, the story continues to each person's arc, detailing the events that would lead Haruto to end up falling in love (and "love in the flesh") that particular character. Although it should be noted that each arc was very detailed and filled with background story, this failed to leave a deep impression on me. I was so bored with some of the arcs and their overemphasis on feelings and emotion that I even skipped through some parts. I felt bad about it but, hell, I did it anyways. What really made me appreciate the story was Sora's arc at the very end (sorry. only spoiler). The presentation of this arc was what really made it worthwhile to watch to the end. It's common knowledge that incestuous relationships are social taboos; yet, Sora and Haru shared such a close bond that I even wanted them to be together, above all other characters. Haru's dedication to protect Sora's weak body, Sora's determination to be with Haru, her only family left, really challenges the viewer to think about the rules imposed by society- What is right? what is wrong? Even though Haru's once close friends become bitter and angry at his defiance of morality, he perseveres and is willing to face the consequences of his actions. This spur of radiance at the end is what pulled the story up to a 9/10.


Art (10/10)

The style and quality of the art is top tier. Since most of the anime is plagued by tragedies, suspense and melancholy; the art reflects this personality. The characters are drawn with the perfect blend of reality and anime. There are no cases of art that contradict the mood. The entire anime flows with perfect synchronization between story and style. But to mitigate the hunger for chibi of some artists and viewers, this anime even devotes an entire short part at the end of each episodes. Drawn. Simply. Chibi.


Sound (10/10)

It is rare for a section to be devoted to sound, but I feel that a large part of what made Yosuga no Sora so successful was the harmonic flow of the musical composition. Some animes nowadays fail to understand the importance of music in the animation process. Music decides the magnitude of the impact a feeling conveyed in the story can have. Music makes one smile, laugh or cry and the music producers of Yosuga no Sora deserve grand kudos for grasping and using this concept. Yosuga doesn't have special endings or a wide vary of compositions like other animes, but, it doesn't need them. Quality, not quantity is what matters. What Yosuga no Sora does have is one particularly stirring and elegant piece of melancholy composition that plays in the thoughtful and sorrowful scenes. The melody invites the viewer to imagine, to dream, and to picture the sunset sky like the characters in the anime would in order too feel their burdens and emotions. Such a unique experience is simply rare to find in the fast-paced anime evolution of today.


*Note: if you don't believe me that sound is important, turn off the sound in Yosuga and play deathmetal or some random vocaloid song. You won't get the same experience.


Character (8/10)

Yosuga no Sora's greatest achievement in terms of characters is its deviation from mundane precedents. When someone thinks of the lead male protagonist of a harem/romance type, he/she immediately thinks about some pathetic, backboneless sorry excuse for a man who's constantly beaten around by an arrogant tsundere female. I applaud those people for believe that because they are right. However, Yosuga no Sora does not have this annoying characterization. Haru is nice but he isn't backboneless. He does what he believes is best but once a line is crossed, he stands his ground. At the same time, Sora is a bit tsundere, but she's not to the level of tsundere that makes me headwall so hard I fall unconscious. Deeper in the story, I find that Sora's tsundereness (epic new word?) leaves relatively quickly, leaving the personality of a taciturn and cute girl who wants to be together with Haru. Later in the anime, she even attempts to take care of Haru by doing cooking and cleaning- a development that no tsundere girl will ever take in any other anime. With this being said, I believe that Haru and Sora were the starlets in this anime. They represent how characters in romance animes should be, not the uber "YOU PERVERT UGLY PIG GOING TO BEAT YOU SENSELESS but I secretly love you" tsundere girl (seriously, anime girls nowadays are climbing to ridiculous levels of tsundere). Unfortunately, the rest of the cast in the anime fall short Sora's and Haru's level. I found those characters relatively boring and with mediocre design. I was disappointed in the arcs of the other characters and the cheesiness in some of their conversation scenes. 


Overall (9/10)

As seriously one of the best and few romance types I've watched, Yosuga no Sora deserves the widespread acclamation. From innovative personality developments, to detailed plot presentations, to musical pieces that tempt me to pull out my violin in order to practice and play it, Yosuga no Sora epitomizes how a romance anime should be. If the producers were to make the other arcs and characters more interesting, I believe that Yosuga no Sora would well define the next generation of harem/romance anime.

If you saw the beginning, you saw the first episode, I bet most of you were like, "TWINCEST. YES. TWINCEST. OH. YES." or something like that. ...Well maybe your reaction was slightly different.
But after you see the second episode, you kinda get this feeling of anime:
The ones with the boy, who is attractive in some way to the other female characters. He goes around and kisses each of the girls, each in a different arc (becuase it would be wrong if it were in the same arc, wouldn't it?! heh.), making them fall for him, they have sex, and then he moves on, and itjust goes on until he's tapped all the girls in the anime.


...hey, I could be totally wrong, can't I? It is only the fourth episode. Things can change. Hopefully, it will.


As for art and sound, they're both really good. Music sets a good, calm, solitude kinda of feeling and the art can be good, but can be crappy at times as well. 


And the characters...well...they don't seem to have any personalities on them. Especially Haruka, the protagonist. He hasn't even shown a bit of personality. Okay, maybe a bit, but so far we don't really know what kind of guy he is.

Yosuga no Sora, while it is a harem, it is not a goofy comedy like most harems are. The show does have a few moments that you may find funny but it is, over all, incredibly serious in nature. This anime touched me on an emotional level like no other anime (or any other media for that matter) has before. Split into a few different alternate timeline arcs, it shows the viewer that what couldn't really be there, is. The story centers primarily around Haruka Kasugano and the relationships he forges in his life. The story begins with Haruka and his twin sister Sora movingto their late grandfather's house in a small town, after their parents die in an accident.


In four alternate timelines, Haruka falls in love with four different girls. Each of them having their own personal problems. Since Haruka is such a kind and caring person, he does everything in his power to make each of them happy. Because Yosuga no Sora is a mature drama, it should come as no surprise that there are several scenes portraying sex (though no gentitalia is shown). While I found the sex a little off putting, it is presented in a way that actually works well to progress the story and the character development. 


The artwork and sound used set a mood for the story that, while not perfect on their own, fit the show splendidly. The art is very crisp and clean, but I found it to be mediocre at times (this is the only thing keeping me from rating a full ten). The music used shines above the art greatly. The music that is often used during emotionally charged scenes never failed to stir up an emotional response from me. 


Where Yosuga no Sora stands above the rest is in its story and characters. While superficially the characters seem to be the stereotypical harem characters; a meganekko, a moe, a tsundere and so forth, each of them develops well and far beyond these cookie-cutter character types. Each character is well thought out, has a story of their own, and is developed into a believable person. Though Haruka isn’t developed as much as the girls, he does get developed quite a bit. 



The characters are truly at the forefront of the show, and while I loved the story, it can at times seem little more than a means to further character development. That’s not to say that the story isn’t engaging and interesting. The story can be hard to follow, though, as It splits several times at a few important plot points, with little to no explanation on what is happening, showing what would happen if just a specific event were changed. For example If a character had walked away from an event thirty second earlier, they would fall in love with a completely different person. Yosuga no Sora doesn’t just show you what happens, it shows you the repercussions of each and every action the characters make. A common theme that plays out several times is that someone will get hurt no matter what you do.


The story and characters are crafted in a way that gets you invested in what happens on an emotional scale. Over all I would recommend Yosuga no Sora to anyone who values character development and storytelling above everything else.

Gun to my head, if someone asked me to answer the question "Did you like Yosuga no Sora?" truthfully to live, I would say "NO."
*BOOM*
That was the sound of my head exploding. In spite of everything, I actually really liked Yosuga no Sora. Sure, there was too much sex in it for me to feel comfortable watching it. Sure, the incest was too strong that it was very uncomfortable. But, if you got past all that (and it took a lot out of me to get past all that), you would find that this is one of the more well written romance anime I've everwatched.


First off, I've gotta commend the decision to go to the omnibus format for this adaptation against the usual integration of the other heroine's routes into the main heroine's routes. In most visual novel to anime adaptations, this integration usually destroys the flow and the narrative. More importantly though, doing it in an omnibus format would let the respective heroines shine in their own route and give them the ending that they each respectively deserve. Sure, the characters were of the generic variety, each falling into usual character types (hime-sama, imouto, osananajimi, etc.) the show was able to make us care about how their story will turn out.


Another thing, this show has nice music. From the OP and ED (of both the main show and the extra part at the end), to the BGMs used within the show, they complemented the story really well. The music really helped create and accentuate the mood of the anime while the insert sounds (BGMs, SFXs) within the episode was timed well making the audio of the show something to commend it for.


All in all, I really enjoyed watching Yosuga no Sora. Although I wished that they at least toned down the sex scenes because some were just awkward, I'll honestly (and begrudgingly) say that I enjoyed my time with it. 


Will I recommend it to my friends who do not watch anime? No. Heck, I won't even recommend it to my friends who do watch anime. But, if you want to watch a great romance anime, is open-minded enough to understand the story and willing to watch it in a very private place, then, by all means, watch this show. It's really good.


*BOOM*

Story: 6

The story of Yosuga no Sora is based on a Visual Novel/Eroge, and as such follows the different routes via story arcs within. One problem right off the bat is that this branching storyline can be quite confusing for an anime watcher who was not aware of the VN, and it makes scenes repeat themselves. The fact this is done without note, or possibly a brief VN-style choice screen in the anime to show that this was a different branch, makes this aspect of it poorly executed.
Additionally, I personally felt that the first three routes/arcs explored were lackluster. Thedrama felt forced, and as if the story for them was merely thrown together for the sake of having a story. This may actually have been the case, as they are not the "true route" of the VN. The "true route" explored in the final few episodes has a far more dynamic plot than the others, and feels more natural in its execution. It is actually the only route I enjoyed watching in the series.\n\n
The art and sound are where the anime truly shines. Even though the art is nothing spectacular, it's good enough to carry the somewhat heavy (albeit often overdramatic) tones of the anime\n\n
The characters were, for the most part, weak. I feel that rushing four routes into one anime caused all the girls except Sora to come across as generic characters made to fall in love with Haruka far faster than need be. Not a single girl seems to deny having feelings for Haruka, making me see that while most anime play the tsundere card up way too high, this one would have greatly benefited from one.\n\n
All in all, with only one route holding my interest (as well as the quite comedic aftershow the anime has), it feels like 70% of Yosuga no Sora merely existed for the sake of having multiple routes. The good parts of it were great, but the majority was dull, and without the final route this anime would likely recieve a 3 instead of a 5

How can people give just 6.55 for this anime?? It's probably the best incest anime I've ever watched, divided by 4 routes, in each of them the protagonist Haru starts a relationship with one of the girls (and in the end of each episode there's a little story between he and the maid).
The OST is awesome, which was a good surprise for me, the drama isn't bad at all, the sex scenes are ecchi but not closer to be a hentai (some people say that YNS is a hentai but ISN'T)
In Average I gave something about 7-8 because It's a beautiful romance (At least the2 last one routes), peacefull and pleasant to watch, you should watch it!

Alright, before anything else, I would like to say that this anime should ONLY be watched by people whose age ranges from 18 and up. The reason is that it contains sex scenes.
Now that I made myself clear, I can continue with my review.
Yosuga No Sora involves four different stories in 12 episodes. Haru being the main character guy has 3 "what if" stories but in the end, he ends up with Sora--his twin sister. At first, I hated Haru's character because I thought he was a "player", soon enough (after the second story) I realized the first one has nothing to do with thesecond story (that's why in every girl that he had sex with, there's always a "Fin" or "End"). Eventually, after finishing the whole episode, I think it is a "what if" stories (what if he has relationship with that girl or the other) maybe the creator is trying to not disappoint the viewer (if in case they like the other girl). However, that's just my own judgement, I don't know the real reason.


Another clarification is whether it is hentai or not. Well for me, it is not. It has a good story. It has good points in explaining why do they end up like that, twincest I mean. I don't agree with incest though, I just thought that the creator wanted to explain something, that this is not just an anime to feed you with lustful thoughts.


Art was great, very fantasy like. I also dealt with other characters's stories, not only the twin.


Others might like this only because of the fact that it contains such erotic scenes but for others, they might enjoy this one because after all, there is a lesson to be learned.

When watching an adaptation of something, especially of something like a visual novel, the outcomes, as far as I've seen, are rather decent to watch, as for the most part, we have the anime focusing on one specific female for the main protagonist to go after, and fall in love, while having proper development and character growth along the way.  But, Yosuga no Sora, is a special case where...we get something, "more" than that.  
WARNING: This is a review of a dropped series.  
Story (5.21/10) for first story.  (7.21/10) for the short: To be honest, I thought the story would beat least somewhat interesting for this series when I picked it up, and I was sort of right.


The story of Yosuga no Sora is about two twins, Sora, and Haruka, who, after their parents death, move to the countryside in order to "get away" from what happened, and start a new life as two children, living alone.  


Oh, how innocent the synopsis is.  Little did we all know, how messed up and strange it would all turn out.  From the first episode, it was apparent to me that this would all end up in a downward spiral that would throw me into a fit of rage and disgust, reminding me of an anime that shall never be named again.  From the first episode, all of the main females that the anime featured, instantly saw our main protagonist Haruka, and immediately fell for him like a spell was cast on them, thus sparking our "story".


Aside from the anime's mess of an idea, the real killer I felt, was the structure that the anime was presented in.  Through and through, the anime felt just like a visual novel.  It didn't have a nice, easy, progressive story like a normal anime has, it was completely 100% a visual novel.  All of the main females were given separate "endings" where they ended up with our main protagonist, followed by an explicit sex scene that was not censored completely (basically making this hentai).  Not only that, some of the female's arcs were basically stem offs from the arc before it, adding into just how visual novel-esque the show was.  


Focusing on the actual episodes themselves, the entirety of a single episode could be seen as a series of "flags", where the main protagonist improves their relationship with a singular female.  The reason why this is bad, is because there was no cohesion between one scene and another.  They didn't flow together well, and that upset me because I was confused about what was going on, since there was one scene where it was a beach scene, and the next was one that was apparently ONE WEEK LATER.  The lack of this scene cohesion led me to feel even more confused about what was going on, considering the fact that the characters leave the audience in the dark a lot.  


Overall, the story telling and execution for this series was very monotone.  Everything was the same, it followed a specific path that it didn't divert, and it felt all around monotonous, boring, and just plain terrible.


That was just one of the two stories that the anime features.  Unlike most anime, the show actually has a short at the end of every episode, featuring the maid Motoka, and her crazy fantasies in this chibi oriented version of the original story.  Without going into too much detail, I find these shorts to be quite funny and enjoyable, as the characters are portrayed quite differently and hilariously at the same time.  However, it should be noted that the anime still does go into its normal artstyle occasionally, as well as showing those, "explicit" scenes like I mentioned before.


Characters (2.43/10): Don't even get me started with these people.  Our main protagonist Haruka, or the "knight in shining armor with the silver hair", is just so, idiot.  He's extremely generic to the point of having zero personality, seeing as how the whole time, he's just been helping these hoards of girls, before sleeping with them at the end of their arcs.  That's it.  He doesn't get mad much at anything, and I don't really see him as a good character at all.  Sure, he has a good character design, but honestly, he's just a cardboard cutout that has less personality than a brick.


His twin sister Sora has more characteristics, but is just as dull.  From birth, she is shown to have a weak body, and for the most part of the series, stays at home, texting to his older brother, when he'll come home to comfort her.  Considering the circumstances for this series, it's understandable that she's the main female protagonist, as she is the closest one to our main male, and is the first one shown.  But, what makes her bad character-wise, is the small amount of screen time she gets.  Apart from the first few episodes, she's rarely seen, as there's always one long shot where Haruka is talking to one of the other girls, and then there's a small one with Sora, and then switch back, rinse and repeat.  She was never really explored, and it just added to how terrible this cast really was.


The other "main females" I feel are very forced and fabricated.  They all have this trait and story that makes them "unique" and different.  While I will admit that the girls themselves are different and interesting with the circumstances that they are given, they don't really get out of that area of characteristics that they're given, making them somewhat dull and unsatisfying to watch.  Coupled with the terrible storytelling and rushed plot line, as well as the arcic setup that plagues this anime, they weren't really all that interesting to watch, and I felt nothing when watching them cry out their feelings.  


The background characters are very arc oriented as well, and just as terrible as their main character counterparts.  This cast is very disappointing and dull in the least.


Art and Sound (7.21/10): The art and sound is a quite redeeming factor for this series.  The art is quite fluid and crisp-looking, using both a darker palette and a whiter palette for the different moods of the show.  The eye detail isn't overly complex, and the characters look rather simple and good.  


Ahem, one thing though.  The art towards the end of any given arc, is explicit.  As I have mentioned before, this show does have sex scenes in it, and it seems that the creators are proud of it, revealing the girls' nipples, and through any angle except a direct, in your face one, will show you that the characters are in fact, having sex.  Also, the nonstop fanservice was just so moronic and pointless to boot.  Didn't help the series at all.


On that disturbing note, let's talk about the music.  The music is actually pretty decent.  It's very calming and beautifully orchestrated, using a variety of string and light sounding instruments to make this series soothing.  The ED and the OP both have this nice feel.  


As for the short, the short actually does have an ED itself, having an energetic slice-of-life feel to it, completely contrasting what the actual, original series has.


Personal Enjoyment (1.14/10): (I'm going to have fun with this one.)  When I saw the overall score on MAL, and saw the top reviews, I was puzzled on why this series was so back and forth.  Naturally, I went and watched it, only to find out that Yosuga was a mess of epic proportions.  As a fan of the harem genre, I have not seen ANYTHING so terribly executed before.  The story itself made far too many small time skips, as well as stupid character developments that felt so fake and fabricated.  


There was no proper transition from one scene to another, terrible character development, and a plot that made me cringe and face palm so much, that I stopped watching, and read the rest of the series on wikipedia in order to know what happened, because I didn't feel like torturing myself to watch a plot that I didn't enjoy.  


I would not recommend anyone to watch this.  Stay away.  Aside from its above-average aesthetics, Yosuga no Sora: In Solitude, Where we are Least Alone, has no other redeeming factors, as the exposition is hardly what I would call good, the actual story was just screaming for better writing, and a completely pointless and stupid ending from what I've read.  I mean, come on.  They even tell you when the arc is over, by putting the words "THE END" on the screen after it's over.  So, just like the series, I will be doing that too.


THE END


Overall score: 4.83/10

Hi! Robert's Too Late Reviews here for you, to guide you through another interesting anime series with another two thousand plus word review! This time we're going to be talking about the very interesting 'Yosuga no Sora'. This is a series that eschews some more mainstream conventions in the way it presents its story, which gives is a bit of a somewhat unique flavor. The quick of it is I would recommend this anime as long as taboo relationships and sexual content was not an issue for the viewer. Will this translate to a space on the coveted RTLR wall of awkwardness? Read on!
Story: 8
Thereis a bit of a spoiler that *must* be taken in context when talking about the show, that being the inclusion of a incestuous relationship between a pair of fraternal twins. This is the taboo relationship I mentioned there in the opener. Now to break down what we have. This series is listed as a 'harem' style, but it doesn't fit that bill in the more traditional sense. We do have the guy twin pursuing and having sexual and romantic relationships with multiple girls, but they are not presented, for the most part, as running concurrent to each other. Instead what we have is two of the four girls that he romances are presented as differing branches of the plot line. After romancing the first girl, the series resets to a moment before that relationship started, and with a slight variation on the scene, the guy develops a relationship with a different girl. After that arc completes, the series resets again to an earlier point, and a third girl is up to bat. This arc, the third girl, appears to be the 'true ending' arc, and her reset point is not before the relationship began, but instead mid way through it, when the guy twin changes speed and romances his twin sister. 


So what we have here is a story that diverges basically three times, and then it cuts halfway back into the third to form the fourth and final story line. Think of this as branching paths, with a good bit of resemblance to the Fate series, where small alterations lead to big changes in the way the story plays out. Because we see that with every girl the story changes, the guy twin is not a 'harem king' playing a group of women. He may seem like quite the ladies man but that's only because we, as the audience, see him with each girl. In the timeline, if you want to go at it with a Star Trek bend, he only has one romantic partner per mirror 'universe'. So he's not rocking a hottie on one arm and another on her knees, this isn't Highschool DxD or anything. It's an interesting variation on the harem genre. Also of note, in the end he does pick a final girl to be with, instead of juggling several. 


There are elements in each romance that engage in some world building. We learn about the individual stories of the different girls, and how they relate to each other. We learn about a couple of the girls' parents, and while the reset may erase the romantic encounter of each girl with the guy twin, the information gained about the lives of these girls appears to remain valid, enriching our view of their lives. 


Moving forward, the series does feature a good bit of sexuality. The guy twin has sex scenes with each of the four girls, and while they are a little gratuitous, they are nevertheless important to the character building. If you're thinking hentai or something that is good for *ahem* self stimulation, you're barking up the wrong tree here. This is not Kissxsis by any stretch. In fact I would say that the story could not be properly told without at least the final two girls having their sex scenes, as they are integral to the overall plot. So, yeah, likely this isn't something you want to take in while in public places, or with kids around. 


Outside of the sexual pieces of the plot we do see surprisingly well laid out side stories to add to the overall experience. The first two girls share an interesting secret together and as the situation is worked through, the series makes a strong point on considering one's perception vs a 'God's eye view' of the world. Judgments passed and assumptions made are shown to be premature and limiting. The anime makes a very good point about the old saying "There are two sides to every story". The exploration of this theme runs throughout the series, and I think was very good at catching the proper notes to engage the viewer. When we are presented a view from one character's perspective, it's easy to agree with her and her judgment of another character, only for us to find out that she, and by extension we, were wrong about what we thought was the truth, because things are usually more complex than they may appear from just one person's point of view. 


The story is filled with asking who's right and who's wrong, and who gets to make that judgment to start with? These questions bring the anime to rise above the 'omg sex!' and 'twincest = wincest' tropes, if my perspective is considered. And if you've made it this far, seems as though that point of view is being sought!


Art: 9

I find the art in this anime to be really great. I love twin girl Sora's entire appearance, with the long silver/white hair, and the rest of the girls are all well drawn too. The girls are easy to identify which is important because there are several, with a couple girls tossed in that aren't part of the 'harem'. The lines flow well. The only knock I would have is that the colors are a bit subdued for my liking, I like a bit more vibrancy, that's just my perspective however. My other only knock is the overdrawn sex bits. The girls' breasts seem to explode into blimps whenever they remove their tops. This isn't terribly surprising, but a little annoying when it happens.


Sound: 10

Absolutely loved the music. There is a great deal of wonderful piano work throughout the series that served to illustrate every bit of the scene on the screen. The music moved through and helped pull emotions out of me without being overly noticeable. The goal of good soundtrack music is to facilitate the flow of emotions without overly complicating or becoming too overbearing. Many times I would feel myself swept into a moment by the music as I was focusing on it for this review. Wonderful music. The opening and closing songs are just as fitting, and worth a listen. I especially loved the upbeat music at the 'specials' as well. 


The voice acting is well done also. I really enjoyed twin girl Sora's voice actress, and the rest of the girls have similarly well matched voices to their personas on screen. The only other guy in the series is the guy twin's buddy, and his voice is hilarious. Overall just loving the music and sound. 


Character: 8

The characters are all likeable and well represented. The rich girl is aloof without being inaccessible, the shrine maiden is exceptionally kind and good hearted, and the girl twin is powerfully, and awesomely, bitchy most of the time. The guy twin might seem too well versed in getting laid, but like I said that's a perspective issue we have as viewers. He's not a total ladies man, we only think so because we see the different romance arcs as viewers. 


The girl twin is very sickly and frail, triggering the guy twin to be protective of her, and this leads to the eventual, predictable ending. She has a powerful hatred of the third girl the guy dates, and the feeling seems pretty mutual, though the girlfriend does try to reach out to the twin. 


The first girl romanced, the rich girl, has a maid who falls for the guy twin, and in the 'specials' that were included at the end of each episode (at least from the source I watched) spends most of the specials trying to sex the twin guy up, with hilarious results for her delusions. They harpoon the most dramatic elements of the series in these little add-ons, and made me laugh out loud more than once. I guess this means the guy twin sort of romances five girls instead of four, though the maid's romance is purely in her own at times perverted mind. 


The only major kicker character wise that really threw me for a loop is when the incest comes to be known by the third girlfriend and another girl. They tell the guy twin that they will not reveal the secret of the incest to others, no matter how disappointed and disgusted they were. Now to me as an American, this seemed odd. Over here, if you have juicy gossip on someone, *especially* during one's high school ages, that info would be shouted from the rooftops. Perhaps that's a cultural thing, that the Eastern viewpoint is much more subdued and less likely to feature rumor mongering when compared to us more crass Westerners. Maybe its just a story decision. I know where I'm from, if one was caught in an incestuous act, within an hour the entirety of the high school would know, and by two the entirety of the city would as well. I won't say that's a complaint per se, just a bit of characterization that doesn't match my experiences with teen aged scandals. 


Enjoyment: 8

Even with the rather taboo subject, and the abundance of sexual situations, I found that I still enjoyed the series a great deal, especially those moments that made me stop and think on the old principle of "judge not, lest ye be judged". I found it thought provoking to show the flaws in the characters' perceptions as they learned the whole truth and had to deal with the fallout of such knowledge. I'm not one to shy away from taboo subject matter such as the incest found in this anime, and I will say that outside a few kind of fanservicey scenes, the relationship is handled fairly maturely. Instead of relying solely on the titillation inherent in such a pairing, they developed the characters where their interdependence allowed for them to question the concept of what their relationship could or could not be. They were a family of only two, all that each other had left, and who can say how they move through the world? Who gets to make that judgment call? 


I of course do not support the idea of incest or anything like it. The point is, that this anime is asking us to challenge our perceptions and ideas, to review them and find assurances that our decisions are based on as whole of a truth as we can discover from our viewpoints. In light of this, my judgment dictates that I do not support incestuous relationships, but the point of the series I think, was not to delight in the incest, but instead to search ourselves for our own truths. To ask the question, who can decide who we love? Is the heart free to do what it wills? What boundaries exist? Who decides them? Can we force those boundaries on others? Very thought provoking questions, even if my answer did not change after searching my feelings for the truth. The journey of asking these questions is where the enjoyment of the series comes from. For the RTLR wall, girl twin Sora scores a spot, because I have an overwhelming soft spot for mean girls. Tsundere perhaps, is the term? If I can't call my partner 'Devil Woman' then I'm not likely to allow them to be a partner in the first place! If you're looking for hentai-like material, then move on along. If you are down for a mature look at these deeper questions, I think you might agree with me that this series deserves a thumbs up.

Yosuga no Sora(YnS) starts strong, a solid premise filled with controversy that promises to deliver the drama aspect, set the tone for romance, but very quickly goes downhill in every aspect it could.
This review will contain mild spoilers, as it would be very hard to explain how the show falls flat without doing so.
YnS's first "flaw" comes from it's episodic nature. By eliminating an overarching plot, you need to lay great foundations for a show to work, you will need to pull out all the stops with art, you will need to have a great cast, and mostly, good writing so as to keep theepisodic nature in check.

YnS fails to do so.


____

Story:

 The story and entire plot of YnS revolves around our two twins, and how they will adapt to their new environment, more specifically, the show will show various alternative timelines/universes/wathever floats your boat about what could have happened to the twins in the town.


The short timelines last between 4 to 2 episodes. And unfortunately, will not be unique, cliche will be a word very present in most of these short timelines. Except for one of them, who, will, for the most part, be the product of what I believe to be, poor writing.


The overused "ideas" and the "bland" writing of the these mini arcs land the show a poor 3 story wise.


____

Art:

Here is where the show will fall flat on it'is face right away. The art, is bland, boring and non-appealing, nothing in it will feel rememberable, as the show chooses to use extremely undetailed rough backgrounds, or showing long and akward still shots.


When animation comes into play, the keyword here is, inconsistency. For the most part, the show barely animates characters, speaks will move to a mostly still frame, and cameras will be paned to force an angle where you may only see movement from the speaker, thus trying to cover it's flaws.


But I did mention inconsistency, so, as you'd expect, there are moments of great animation, let me break it to you, the show will have sex scenes. And here is where they will be beautifully animated, all the budget went here, the movements look fluid, and most of the time natural, hell, I've seen hentai with worser animation than these scenes. These scenes manage to scrap the art to an average of 5.


____

Sound:

Similar to the art, but not on such extreme levels, the soundtrack the show uses is fitting, but unmemorable, I finished it 30 minutes ago, and I couldn't tell if a song played in the show if I listened to it right now, the OP works, the soundtrack works, and the ED fits, but where the show does show good work, is on character voicing, yet again, these sex scenes blew the budget, with really adequate voice for the cast.


____

Character:

Oh boy, here we go. You know this would happen when you saw Harem in the tags right?

It is here that the show's flaws really start to drag it down, 90% of the cast, are cliche tropes we are used to seeing. The MC is a self-insert , he has no hobbies, passions or dreams, all he seems to care about his wathever girl the mini arc in question chooses to focus. His twin sister, perfectly matches the standarts of younger sisters, a dash of tsundere, a little touch of loli, some shyness, and voulla, bland imouto is born. The same is true for the rest of the cast, we have the "perfect" rich girl, the good old glasses oppai-neechan, the clumsy energetic girl, hell, we even have the comedic relief only other male in the group.


Ally bland base characters, with lazy and unrealistic character progression and interaction, and you have what we call, a dreadful cast.


____

Enjoyment:

The show is unwatchable with critical thought present. 16 year olds keep breaking into awkward sex scenes and tongue kisses. We are talking rural teenagers, whose ideal relationship seems to turn into sex every half minute. Don't get me wrong, the sex scenes while well animated and voiced, completely break suspension of disbelief, as they will not be what you'd expect from teenagers, first timers, such and such.


To name one, and this sentence will spoil a bit, you will get to see a 12 year old girl, rape a 12 year old boy because of emotional instability.


Again, see what I mean by poorly written interaction?


____

Overall:

YnS had everything it needed to suceed, but awkward writing that looks to have been made by a horny teenager or some very... unreliable adult ultimately bring it to it's demise. A show without a plot per say cannot afford to have terrible and unoriginal cast, and worse, horrendous writing.

We get it, the message covered in the last arc about love transcending all barriers bla bla. Good intentions don't make a good show. YnS would have been far more sucessfull add it' author decided to simply write adult works instead of shoving a hollow show full of sex scenes and cringeworthy interactions.

THIS SHOW IS DISGUSTINGLY HOT

The art is really good, but they have some strange bloom / blur affects sometimes that make no sense.
Some of the side characters seem to have no reason to be there except to tantalize the brother.
Sound is pretty great.
Characters are DISGUSTINGLY HOT.
not very enjoyable though. Pretty boring at times. Especially at the ends of episodes strangely.
If you enjoy dialogue-heavy anime, or you enjoy strange sexual encounters, this might be the show for you. If you want comedy, don'tgo anywhere near this. If you want action, the closest you're getting is when they fall off the bike. lol.

Yosuga no Sora may get way more hate than it may deserve, but I'm genuinely surprised that people are going so far as to give the show 9 and 10/10s, or even 7 and 8/10s. I wouldn't give the show anything above a 5/10, as I believe Yosuga no Sora doesn't have anything innovative or genuinely interesting going for it other than its handle on taboo relationships.
Story: 6/10. The show is basically split into arcs that focus on Haruka's relationship with a specific 'girl-of-the-week', and over the course of 3 or so episodes we see the relationship between the two develop in its entirety. Theserelationships usually ending in an explicit love-making scene btw, so if you don't want to see anything like that definitely don't watch this show.


The arcs themselves aren't really memorable, but they're not as bad as I expected. The show attempts to give background and context to the girl's situation and perspectives, and we see how Haruka is introduced to and fits into this girl's own world. While you'll probably forget what happened in an arc once it finishes and the next one rolls in, I'd say each arc is at least made so that you want to see where things end up.


The final arc of the show is what makes Yosuga no Sora infamous, and therefore I believe it's the most memorable one of the show. It showcases a taboo relationship and, while I still don't buy the romance that occurs or think the characters have chemistry at all, I think it's at least not in overwhelming BAD taste, which I expected it to be. 


Art and Sound: Nothing bad but nothing outstandingly great either.


Character: 5/10. The characters in Yosuga no Sora can be classified into three categories: useless, useless until an arc calls for them to be a romantic interest, or Haruka. When a character is in the second category, there's a fair amount of characterization and development to be had. Otherwise, the character is forgettable or just a bland agent through which the romance can proceed. 


Enjoyment: 6/10. I came into the show thinking it would be pretty horrible, but the story-lines for each arc have some meat to them and there are genuinely interesting plot-threads and character developments that occur. 


Overall: 5/10. This show isn't something I would recommend people to watch, as I believe it's at best a forgettable romance and at worst a show that can make others uncomfortable. It wasn't as bad as I expected it to be, but it only manages to scratch the surface on how to do romance right and, in the bigger picture, comes off as an unmemorable show with forgettable characters.

I was genuinely shocked when I finished this anime for the first time. Upon looking at it and the genres it entailed, I thought that it would be a bit strange and that it wasn't any different from another harem/ecchi anime, but that couldn't be further from the truth. For only having 12 episodes,  the character development in this show is fantastic, you really get a backstory and a lot of detail about each girl and Haru as well. The music is what kept me on the hook, the song Kioku is one of the most beautiful pieces I've ever come across in ananime and have since learned it on guitar and piano. A lot of people bash this anime for having incest, but if you watch it with an open mind and look at the messages behind it, the true beauty lies within. You can't help who you fall in love with, and that love is universal. The story was very sweet and left me with an instant want for more content, so I purchased the Blu-Ray Box set and the visual novels for a more in-depth story. The sex scenes added to the story, in my opinion, because they really fit the mood and the character's feelings at the time. A lot of stories these days stray away from a "happily ever after" ending because it's too cliche, but I was beyond happy this story ended happily between the two siblings. It was a beautiful change of pace from other romance anime I've seen and this has jumped straight to my #1 favorite. Fantastic work. 10/10.

Now looking at the general rating of this show, it's obvious that it's pretty low, mainly because of the h-scenes and dark concepts but it's definitely an entertaining watch.
The story is split into 4 arcs, each arc consisting of a different character for our main protagonist Haruka to end up with. Each character arc has its own little message and problem that is quick but easy to follow. It doesn't go to deep since they can't contain a ton of development in 2 episode per character but it's a pretty interesting watch.
Now what I mean by dark concepts, I mean an arc involving incest, nowdon't judge me but this is, in my opinion, the best arc in the anime. It goes pretty deep in its concept and should get some of you to think about it.


As I said, this show isn't really character driven, each character (except a couple) get their own minor backstory but in general its not like the characters are completely generic but their not the most detailed either. But either way, most likely you'll find a character to get attached to and love the arc that they get.


Art is beautiful, I love the visuals of the scenic backgrounds and the characters. Compared to the visual novel however, I prefer some characters (specifically my waifu Sora) in it rather than the anime


Sound...Jesus I wish there was an 11 on this rating. The music is gold. Absolute gold, mainly focusing on the soft and sweet piano, guitar and violin type stuff and it gets me, EVERYTIME. It really contrasts the scene as well! You can literally download the song and play it when you're having a relaxing day and just fall asleep to it. It's beautiful.


I enjoyed this a lot. Not for the h-scenes (or maybe the h-scenes) but for the short and pleasant conflicts with each character and beautiful music and art. This show deserves a chance so give it one and if you don't like the h-scenes, you have many choices. Skip the scene, watch it censored, or stop being a wuss and live with it, you aren't 5 anymore buddy.


But yeah this show is awesome, and Sora will always be my guilty pleasure.

Brief Description: YOUR HAPPINESS IS OVER SOCIETIY'S PREJUDICES.
This is my first review, and I actually registered because I wanted to leave an opinion on this marvelous anime. (bare with me)
Story (10/10): I usually like when visual novels are adapted to anime as if they where visual novels, with many different arcs.Why? because (for example in yosuga no sora) each girl has the opportunity of getting to be with the character, so we've got many possibilities to choose instead of asking ourselves what would have happened if?. I think that this kind of anime gave the opportunity for the viewer to choose their own "happy ending"and I liked the way they develop each arc bearing in mind the few chapters each one of this arcs had. 


Art (8/10): Good art, I actually liked the design of Sora and Haruka, because in many animes that treat incest, none of the brothers/sisters are similar in any way so it makes it much more cute to watch if the brothers are actually blood related. (yes, I think incest is alright)


Sound(8/10): I liked the soundtrack of the series, I think it actually gave an extra touch to the mood of the story and I think the Soundtrack fitted into the scene it was alright for me.



Enjoyment(10/10): The reason for me to enjoy the series that much is, because for the first time ever I saw a half hentai/almost hentai series, in where I felt a love mood in the characters when the H scenes appeared. The characters really where showing love to each other rather than just having sex and that made me love the anime more than I would usually do with a normal ecchi anime from this kind. (kiss x sis)


Overall(9/10): This anime had a great plot, good animations, good sound and I enjoyed it very much. Every episode was way better than the last one and I would recommend it to anybody who isn't against any taboo. I gave it a 9 because for the first time in my history as an otaku I've seen an anime character who have sex with the females because he loves them and really cares for their sake, and because the process for having sex has a good development rather than an accident followed by "mutual comprehension of why we both want pleasure". 


I also liked the dilemma that comes up with the series ¡what is more important, your happiness or what society believes? and ¿are you really willing to sacrifice your image towards society for your happiness?


To conclude, the reason for which i didn't give the series a 10/10 was because although it was beautiful, it was not realistic, in life not everything can come up as you planned it and I think that the drama in the series wasn't well developed enough for me to believe that the main event in the series (final arc) was believable. But at the same time enjoyed this surrealism that permited several possibilities in the series, that permitted the many arcs in the series to be.   


Feedback is accepted ;)

Are you looking for an anime similar to school days but without the killings? Well, look no further! Yosuga no Sora is the anime for you!
When I watched this anime for the first time, I thought it would be another typical romance anime with different arcs, but it wasn't. It actually took me by surprise, especially the ero scenes (I was not expecting that). And like the visual novel, it starts and ends at where you make the critical decisions.
Probably what shocked me the most was the topic of incest. It was not just a topic that you can blurt out, but this anime wasbrave enough to bring out it up. And ending a story that started with incest is really difficult. Some would've ended it with suicide or some other depressing ending. But this anime was able to end it happily, although not perfectly.\n\n
Overall, I enjoyed the anime. I recommend this to people who want to fap and cry at the same time. Kidding! But really, if you enjoy romance anime, you'll enjoy it.

Don't get mistaken about this anime.  It's not your typical scenario where some brother and sister argue with each other.  Yes.  It's incest.
Story:
The story was pretty cliche when it comes down to the fact that it's basically a harem where a cool city boy gets all the girls in the country. Even his sister. haha. Anyway, the reason why the story is so weak is because practically all the arcs are repeating themselves.  Yeah sure they're in different situations, but I felt like I was watching the same thing over and over again.  By the third arc it just gotplain ridiculous.


Score: 4


Art:

The art is what caught my attention in the first place and made me want to watch it.  The characters are well designed and everything looks pretty realistic. The angles are well thought out, too.


Score: 8


Sound:

The sound is also good.  The voices match the characters very well and they even caught the sounds of breathing and the chirping of the cicadas.  The soundtrack is catchy and the music is played at the right times. The music also fits the scenes well.


Score:8


Character:

Characters are average.  You have your basic cliche characters included in this anime.  However, the development of the characters was pretty decent because of the fact that most of them were able to solve their past problems with the help of the MC. 


Score: 6


Enjoyment:

I went into this anime knowing that it was going to involve incest.  I didn't mind it, I just felt like the ending was kind of a cop out. Not going to say anymore to spoil it.  And, like I said before, I felt like the arcs were repeating themselves so I found myself skipping the boring parts in the episodes which I typically do not do.


Score:5


Overall: 6

It was not a bad series.  It's worth the try.

If you're a person who is tired of watching a 25+ episode anime full of awkward misunderstandings and embarrassing events with a romance that is as slow as molasses, then this anime is for you.
This anime also has incest and sex scenes, but don't let this stop you from watching it.
Story: 7/10
The only thing that's wrong with the stories is that they don't really have very many episodes, so they can't explore each character and each relationship as much as I'd like them too. However, I believe they were still very well done considering each arc only had 4 episodes to work with.
The romance isvery fast paced compared to other anime, but even so, I didn't feel like any of the arcs were rushed. They were all satisfying short stories.




Art: 9/10


I loved this show's art. Everything from the intimate scenes, to the backgrounds were well done. Really beautiful for (what I assume) is a standard budget show.




Sound 9/10


This has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. The staff did a good job picking the right songs for the right moment for maximum impact, plus the music itself is beautiful on its own.


I'm not someone who is qualified to judge voice actors, but the voices all seemed natural to me and the emotion was flawlessly conveyed. I am speaking of the Japanese voice actors here. I haven't heard it in any other language.




Character: 8/10


Each character has their own story that gets explored, but not in a lot of detail. They did well developing each character with the time they were allotted.




Enjoyment: 9/10


This anime was like a breath of fresh air to me. It has an MC with a pair of balls, fast paced; yet well done romance, and it also has tastefully done H-scenes that depict the intimacy and affection the characters have for eachother.



Final thoughts:


If the sex scenes are what is holding you back from starting this show, then I understand, but they are not your typical tacky sex scenes that are depicted in hentai. You can feel the emotions the characters have for eachother.


If the incest is what's holding you back, I have to say that it is very well done too imo, because in this anime, it has consequences, and is dealt with seriously. The MC has a realistic internal struggle with himself over whether it is right, or wrong, and how his peers will perceive him if/once they find out.


If you are 100% unable to watch incest, then I think you're missing out on the rest of this show, and I suggest that you watch it but skip the last 4 episodes (the incest arc).


Thanks for reading.

Lately, there appears to be no end to shows that wink at incest. This show is an adaptation of a PC adult game, with a relationship between siblings as its central point. These two facts automatically mean there are certain things to expect and to not expect from Yosuga no Sora.
Well, let's face it. You decide to watch Yosuga no Sora. Chances are, you're here to see how different this particular approach on this taboo of a relationship will be. Yosuga no Sora is not Kiss x Sis. And I'm not talking about the blood relation. You don't have this constant, mindless jumping into smut.Yosuga no Sora is no Koi Kaze either. Here, fan service is an important ingredient of the show, and the psychological approach of the matter isn't as deep, apart from some meager attempts of the male protagonist to resist his urges.


So what is there to expect of Yosuga no Sora? Expect..Highly polished graphics. Nicely drawn, attractive characters -it's a 2010 production after all. Expect some nice opening and ending themes. In fact, I enjoyed their visual aspect more than the actual songs, but still. While watching them expect some recurring visions of symbolisms like...trains. The world outside the window. Pure white. The feeling of being sick.


Following the nature of these games, expect four different arcs, where all the different "paths" for Haru, the male protagonist, are explored. Expect some voice acting by Sora's seiyu. I can't find the right words to express it right now. She's lazy, needy, clingy, spoiled. This fever she's running, it's in her voice too. The rest of the voice acting was indifferent to me. Expect...To be honest, I didn't expect the OST to be this good. These piano pieces can be very sentimental. It was the music, and the direction at times too, that created this constant feeling that..something wicked this way comes. It's a feverish condition, that they're bound to give in to in the end. Of course, expect lots of sexual tension through out; And some funny comedy clips at the end of the episodes, which are being honest about this too. 

Now, what is there not to expect. The sexual tension to be there all the time. And I don't mean this in a good way. 


Three episodes for each arc keep things short, which can be good and bad at the same time. Paths you don't find interesting don't last long. But it doesn't leave enough space for development. Sora is meant to be the star of this show though, and the Haru-Sora arc progress through out, with the little things we learn about them.

The first arc kept my interest, since I wasn't aware of this "path" structure of the show. Still, can't miss the weaknesses. They've drawn an attractive girl. They made her rich, so she's that stereotype, who is bound to have family issues too. But she needs something more to be special. Oh, I know. Why not just..throw a violin in there.

Then we have the second arc. Which, to me, was more like a chore, than the work of chemistry. The feeling I got was "Alright, we have to try this pairing too. Let's get this over with". That's how shallow it was. But it was during the third arc that this show shone...as a comedy.


It's not easy to be so funny. I don't know where to start. From this "Ohai. I'm a preteen. I'm sad. What do I do about it..! I know! I rape another preteen!" attitude? From these ridiculous smiling sex faces, which destroy any intentions of sensuality? The part where the girl is supposedly devastated afterwards, walking away in a slow, dramatic way - which resembles watching a retarted zombie walking instead? And how can I not find it hilarious, how can I not pause to laugh, when Nao and Haru decide to search for Sora? Aren't you going overboard when you have the GIRL looking MANLY when she runs, and the MAN running with his hands going left and right, in this famous girlish depicting of running?


Am I being too harsh? Actually, I'm being too lenient. I wondered whether I'm exaggerating over small things, that others wouldn't notice. But no. This is not a child's show; It shouldn't be at least, with a thematology like this. Haru is sky(=Sora)-bound, but people uninterested in some specific themes are unlikely to be captured by this one.

OK I first heard about this series from a friend and what I heard on  the net. Incest was the only word use the describe this series so even thou I intended to watch it to see what all the talk was about, I put it off for a while as I expected it to be a series a incest one through and through. 
Boy was I wrong. This show was NOT what I was expecting. OK, being made from a visual novel, the series has content. Alot and even more could of gone in it but that's something else. 
There are several girlsand one main male protagonist. The series is divided into arcs and as you can guess, each arc focus on one girl in terms of romantic relation wise. If you have seen Amagami SS then its like that but with sex between the pair. Sex scenes are in it but its not hardcore hentai. Soft-hentai it you must. These sex scenes happen mostly towards the end of the arc. This makes up and give significant meaning towards the story arc. The two last episode are questionable as it threatens our morality of whats right and whats wrong when it comes to these things but I believe that you should be your own judge of that. \n\n
Don't expecting "forbidden love" throughout the series like I did base on hearsay.

First off, think the concept of turning an adult (ish) romance visual novel into anime is somewhat wrong. That being said, this one turned out great as far as i think.
The different stories are clearly marked, so you know when one ends and another unrelated one starts. The characters are mostly well made and thought out, the emotional parts are well made and integrated with the music (the music is good.. but very repetitive, so it gets a bit of annoying). Each arc progresses quickly and feels complete (even though they are so short). There is some comedy involved that helps lighten the sad partsand prevent it from getting depressing. The adult scenes integrate almost perfectly with the normal ones, and feel right and not forced or fan servicy. \n\n
In short, i'd say the rank of 7/10 or slightly more is well deserved for this anime. As a romance anime however, i'd say it deserves around 9 / 10, as it feels much more complete in that aspect than most romance anime i watched as the most of them have pretty much no closure to them. It is a bit hard to switch and follow the different arcs separately, and that is what ruins it a bit for me, but i'd still recommend this to anyone looking for a romance anime.

Right, it's been a while since I wrote a review but I literally just finished watching this series so it's fresh in my head.
Yosuga no Sora is another anime based on a visual novel that has followed the Amagami SS way of doing things. Every girl gets a short arc and timeline where they get their spotlight. Personally I really like this concept as it stops people complaining about who the protaganist winds up with. My own personal complaints being with Clannad for example. However I digress.
Story: 7
The story begins like pretty much any other anime of the genre where the protaganist (Haruka) and hissister (Sora) move to a place they used to live as kids minus any parents/guardians. There are a few interlinking features between stories and the final arc with Sora is wonderfully provocative. The thing is though, I have never seen an anime with the Twincest twist to it and never thought I would ship it but when you see for yourself, I'm pretty sure you will feel the same as they do about it all as they fight with morality. The story would score higher but the other arcs are fairly cliche, the saving grace being that Haruka isnt a gibbering idiot and can actually get somewhere with the girl in question.


Art: 9 


The art is very crisp, especially during Ecchentai (kinda half and half) scenes. It would be quite hard not to look at Sora in a lustful way if she looked like she does in her scenes. Even the ending ministories which are drawn mostly in a chibi style have a distinct cuteness to them which makes them appealing.


Sound: 8


The OP was fairly average as I only listened to it for the first 2 episodes. However the ED is a bit more catchy and will probably be on my download list soon. The music is fairly atmospheric and captures the mood well and of course the VA's in both ecchi and non ecchi scenes perform admirably. Crap VA's would probably have ruined this.


Character: 9


There is a character for everyone in here depending on what tickles your fancy. Tsundere, the Big Boobed Childhood friend with added glasses, a Miko, a Maid, a rich girl and even a prude in the background. Whichever your preference is, I guarantee at least 1 arc will appeal to you. In my case I had 3.


Enjoyment: 9 


Scenes were executed really well and some things made me cringe whereas others made me laugh. The miniseries that is tacked on to the end adds a light heartedness to what could be considered a mostly serious romance. The Huge head on Akira never ceases to make me laugh. One of the funniest things I've seen in ages.


Overall: 8


Overall I score this a solid 8 as there was room for improvement, perhaps an arc with the class president would have been possible. I feel a more conclusive ending would have been a nice thing to add as well.


All in all I view this anime as more than just a fapfest, its actually a close up view of morals and standards in todays society, at least from the last arc. That's what I take from this anyway.

I absolutely ADORE Yosuga no Sora. My dirty-ass mind went straight to this gem once I heard it was full of taboos and sex. What can I say, I’m a hot blooded woman. And boy, did it live up to the hype and then some!
Before I delve deeper into my personal feelings, let’s take a gander at the hot names involved with the show and other projects they’ve worked on, just to get an idea about the quality.
Director: Takahashi Takeo – Spice and Wolf, Love Hina, and Citrus.
Producer: Yamanaka Takahiro – Toradora and Kokoro Connect 
Sound Director: Iwanami Yoshikazu – Ghost in the Shell, JOJO,and Kill La Kill, and One Punch Man Season 2. 


As you can see, Yosuga no Sora isn’t just some run-of-the-mill Harem, as I’m sure most of us expected. It offers a complex peek into forbidden love and the trauma’s that follow. It’s more than just T&A (which is still offered, abundantly).  


Story: Normally I don’t like episodic plots. Not to say Yosuga no Sora is episodic, but it’s also not completely linear. Based on an ecchi video game, the show mimics the “one guy bangs multiple girls” plotline. Every 3 or 4 episodes the story resets, each time featuring a new girl for our main protagonist to date. Here’s the hook, the last arch features his twin sister as his lover. INCEST ALERT! I enjoyed the last arch the most. These episodes are the steamiest, darkest, and most fascinating to watch. Do I condone insect? Not particularly. Yet, I’d be lying if I said I didn’t hope to see them get together. 


Sound: I was immediately blown away by the musical score. My initial reaction was HOLY SHIT THE MUSIC IS SO GOOD. I still listen to the main melody all the time. The sombre score fits perfectly with the grim theme and tormented characters. As a stand-alone soundtrack, you can’t get much better than this. If you’re unsure, go to YouTube and have a listen. You won’t be disappointed.  


Art: Two words describe the animation: absolutely gorgeous. Set in rural Japan, the art captures the tranquil majesty of nature. Every episode feels comfy and serene. The calm setting wonderfully offsets the intense drama. I loved the character designs and the overall quality of the art. You will not find girls with breasts larger than physically possible or chibi versions of the characters.  


Characters: Although the show classifies as an Ecchi, it doesn’t avoid darkness and despair. I appreciate when the plot explores the psychological depth of young love/lust. Each character brings some sort of mental turmoil to the plot without coming off as whiny. 


Enjoyment: Overall, I extremely enjoyed Yosuga no Sora. The show not only met my expectations, it surpassed them. Is the show a high brow contender for mass commercial consumption? Hell no. It's still an ecchi, but it is the best ecchi you can find. Supurb!

This has been one of those Anime I sit down to watch and expect a bad story. (based on the rating on MyAnimelist).
However... I really liked this Anime because it is unique, has a build-up multidrama and... it's pushing limits.
I think the reason it has such a low score, is because of the ecchi stuff and the.... Scenes...
But that shouldn't matter because the story needed that, and would have been weird without it.
The first Anime I ever watched was Aki-Sora (in 9th grade lol). A friend showed me.
I watched it because it was weird and we never see that kind of content on the Northside of Europe. But this anime is way better, and actually have a good story.


The Anime needs more excitement which will catch people to watch more. The drama wasn't always that intense, and I feel like it needs more of that.


I really liked the ending and the decisions. It was unexpected (for such a unique story) and it felt natural. Only thing being the fast build-up towards the end.


Story (9):

The story is unique but could have had a bit more intense drama.


Art (8):

The art is good, and doesn't stand out in a good or bad way. Some scenes are more detailed than others, eg. when feelings are expressed with body language, and a few emotional scenes.

Art in general is about right.


Sound (10):

As expected. Feelings are also expressed with the tone and variation in the voices and music of course.

I also like the Music.


Characters (8):

There are always characters we like and don't like, and I think it should have been a bit less drama and focus around a few.


Enjoyment (8):

As said, the build-up in the end was too quick, but the unique story and drama makes it good anyways.


Overall I give it a 9.

This is not Hentai, it's a love story.
