Yosuga no Sora is not all that it seems. I'm not saying that it's bad; it's just not all that it seems and that is the best I can describe it.
At first glance, it's slightly appealing because some of us out there like the incest stories. Immediately, we're ready to see how the main character and his sister develop an intimate relationship. Here's the catch, though: this anime adaptation goes along the lines of the "arc" or "route" structure. It's good and bad, enjoyment wise. My rating for story, a 7, goes for the final arc.
I believe in this adaptation, the arc structure is placedso that we can get to know the characters. In the end, all of the characters have some significance. You can skip to the end if you really want to, but otherwise, Yosuga no Sora would have been an OVA.


Now, we move on to the general atmosphere of the show. It will involve humor, melodramatic subplots, and soft-core hentai scenes which will leave you stunned in surprise at times because of how they fit in the subplots/plot. Not all people can bear with the subplot content so they drop it altogether. The branching routes are hardly memorable, especially when focusing on the latter parts of the series and eventually, the goal of the entire adaptation: the incest. And with this show, the production staff did not hold back on the taboo nor the intimacy. Keep that in mind as you watch.


Now, the art represents the show quite well. A pair of siblings that lost their parents and have to move out to a town they vaguely remember. It's one of those realistic yet colorful types of anime art. It reflects the seriousness and also the lighter parts. The images are sharp enough for me and create a good ambiance.


The music is the same as the art -- highly representative of the story when the situation calls for it. The opening is fitting for the seriousness and the ending sequence is fitting for the lighter side of Yosuga no Sora.


All in all, Yosuga no Sora is a good anime if you want to see a bluntly put incestuous relationship but at the same time build anticipation for it by watching arcs. If you're looking for light humor in it also, it's there and once again -- be aware that most of this is the arc structure!

Would it be bad to say that I was introduced to this anime from my friend who thought it was some hentai? No? Oh good. Yosuga no Sora depicts of a set of Fraternal twins moving into their old childhood hang out in the summer. Hidden pasts, family issues, oh and above all, incest. If you were turned down from any of these words, pklease step away.
The way this story unfolds is as if it was an H game. Oh wait, it is an H game. Yosuga no Sora was originally an H game released back in December 2008.
Now, the story is told in arcs,like the anime and if you didn't wiki search the episode guide, you would probably be lost because at the end of each arc (noted with a black scene saying fin) it goes back to the events after episode 1, ignoring what has happened in the past arc. This type of story telling has its ups and downs. Its good that you can just watch the first episode and skip to the episode of your favorite girl without worry but this causes a lot of confusion and a few key scenes won't be understood if you haven't  seen the last arc.

The bonus segments after each episode are focus more on humor and are less serious.


The animation, as you can tell, looks nothing like the animation from the game. So if you're watching this because you liked the cover art for the game, you will be in for some disappointment.

As for the animation, it seems choppy and sometimes even lazy. A few scenes look as if the characters are dead and apparently no one likes to wear a different cloth style except the ones they've worn since episode 1. Its a bumpy road from wear some scenes seem top notch where others fall flat on their face.'

What really will make your eyes orgasm is how detailed the scenery is. The trees look fantastic and the water looks as if you could drink it. But now and then trees will look horridly grainy and the water will look like pudding.

The bonus segments are animated in a chibi-ish manor and is very cute.


The cast for Yosuga no Sora is quite a handful.

Our main male protagonist is Kasugana Haruka. Out of most male protagonists from other anime, he seems to get the ladies too easy and does it without effort. He has little depth for being the lead and his personality doesn't back him up for it. One thing to touch on him is that most of his interations with the girls in a serious scene are just down weird and comepltely random.

The main heroine of the anime is Kasugano Sora. Her personality is very tsun, like most heroines out there. She gives off a childish personality and goes through the most character change throughout the anime.

The other handful of the heroines are really plain and very similiar in character build up. They all have similar personalities with differences here and there, and all their problems are solved through the same means as the last. The only reason to watch their arcs, excluding Soras's, would be for their looks. for the hentai scene, or out of boredom.

The supporting characters are probably the most unimportant characters you'll see. They will interact with the main cast on few occasions and then disappear for about 2 episodes.


The soundtrack is very melancholic soothing. Enfonius does a great job for the opening and Iwanami Yoshikazu's background music could make you fall asleep. A sad note would be that the same melody for the music is that it repeats the melody a lot and just changes the tempo and instruments. It seems lazy but it works to some degree.


The enjoyment of this anime comes through repetition. Each arc consists of Haruka's interactions between the the chosen girl and the arcs seem to follow the same path. Sora's arc differs alittle only because a girl from a past arc is third wheeling Haruka's romance and that its pure incest. This arc also has the most episodes containing 5 where others contain about 3 to 4.


Overall, this anime is mediocre. Theres better anime like this out there and they won't make you feel dirty after watching it. If your curious about this anime then go ahead and watch it because from my view Sora's arc was actually pretty good. Because for an anime that borders hentai it was fairly decent.

Warning possible Spoilers
Pretty much the message of this anime is if you help out a girl who is in a big situation she will reward you with sex, like that makes any goddamn sense.
The story begins with Haruka and Sora Kasugano who have returned to their home in the countryside try to make a new life after their parents tragic accident, while trying to build a new life they encounter old and new friends that eventually make a big impact on their lives.
Now this anime decides to tell it's stories in 4 different arcs with each one focusing on a different female character and howHaruka solves a situation for them that pretty much ends with him having sex with them.

The first arc is about Kazuha and her relationship with Akira which eventually shows us she is actually Kazuha's secret sister and how this secret ends up changing their friendship until Haruka comes in to help the day.

The second arc is about Akira and pretty much expands upon the whole secret sister situation that she had with Kazuha in the first arc except there isn't as much fighting between the two and there is more mystery instead of drama.

The third arc is about Nao who used to have a complex relationship with Haruka in the past and his sister knows about this so when Nao and Haruka start dating Sora starts to resent Nao until they eventually come to an agreement with each other.

The final arc is pretty much to me the incest arc as it concentrates on the relationship between Haruka and Sora, but when they are discovered having sex by Nao and her friend they start having moral disagreements until they both accept that they are in love with each other and decide to move away.

The fact they decided to do different arcs was interesting, but it just weirded me out how that helping a girl with a big situation ends up leading to sex just completely blew my mind.


The characters were in some case quite complex as their feelings would change a lot over the course of the different arcs along with the actions and decisions they made would often make the characters think about their morals about whether it is right or not especially during the final arc considering Haruka and Sora were brother and sister and in a relationship made the others question them if this was really the right thing to do and if they really wanted this.


The artstyle was at least decent to see since the anime is set in the countryside so we did get to see some nice scenery from time to time and for some reason liked the interior of the houses for some of the characters especially Haruka and Sora's house which looked simple, but cosy to live in.


Now of course the fanservice is very prominent here and when I watched it, it did catch me off guard because it wasn't something I was expecting, I certainly wasn't expecting Haruka to have sex with each of the girls at the end of the arcs and when I saw the harem tag I thought this was going to end up a mess, but luckily this story wasn't linked together.


Now the romance was different for each character since they all had different personalities and different tie's to Haruka, some were old friends while others were new people it just doesn't make sense how helping a girl sort out a big situation ends up with you having sex with them although Haruka has sex with Nao and Sora before the arc even ends so yeah, but it just confused me really how just doing a task like this would end up with you getting laid, then of course is the incest stuff which is something I am not comfortable with and honestly I though Haruka and Sora had a bit of an age difference yet they are the same age which was surprising to me, but again it just felt awkward and uncomfortable seeing them have sex especially when one time was right at the door making it easy for someone to stumble onto them having intercourse which is exactly what happened and it was such a hilariously awkward moment.


Overall this was a strange anime that really caught me off guard with the stuff that happened and I wouldn't recommend this unless you are willing to find out just how ridiculous it is.

First off, some notes:
* Does feature actual sex, detailed, several times
* Is not a porn/hentai, ecchi, or cheesy fanservice-based anime at all
* Does feature incest
Not your average "harem" anime. Quite the opposite - this is a genuine love story.
Not only is it a dramatic, genuine and romantic anime that, despite its tropes of multiple women loving the main character, avoid unnecessary fanservice-based narratives quite well - but it also, despite many of the characters being pretty "typical", manages to involve these characters in ways where they not only show color, but develop strongly as characters.
I find it displeasing when animes feature "fanservice" by simply creatingawkward tease-like situations and try to build a story around it. You can have 20 women marvelling over the main character, yet nothing sexual, not even a kiss, is allowed to occur naturally. 


In contrast, this anime is a fresh breath of air and actually *does* bring characters through the *entire* process. Sex happens. Detailed, too. But not in a cheap or pornographic focus.


All in all, the anime carries you from start to finish without any major hiccups. And you could argue that many of the possible "flaws" are really just a choice of design and direction, as well as the desire to stay true to the nature of anime and not turn this into something it shouldn't be.


I do miss some "more" content. I do miss some variation, some more action/excitement, some more indebth personal moments that don't jumpcut ahead, and distractions and travels that add to the feeling of the anime without having to be solely centered on the main characters. All in all, there could be more "stuff going on".


** Slightly spoiler-like facts**


This anime sure acts as a very laid-out adventure, and does not leave you empty or upset at what it tries to do. It leaves you with something that most anime simply don't fease; the denied and overlooked possibility of combining a conclusive-enough ending, with the excitement and curiosity for the future.


All in all, not only was the story believable and exciting enough, but the ending was just outright good, in a way that makes you go "Finally! An ending that isn't stupid."


Could I improve the ending? Yes. But it depends on whether I *want* to go in that direction. And thus, is it really a needed improvement, or simply just a roadblock for a possible future that could be differently interesting in a followup season? Who knows..


As of my 2017 edit of this review, this is one of my highest rated anime.


If you're wondering what to watch next, but might like a juicy anime with honest and fulfilling romance, and perhaps a little bit of taboo, this might be for you.

When I watched this anime I was struck by how much the plot resembles a dating simulator. I did not find the plot profound like some reviewers here, though it was cute and at times very well done for a short anime. 
Here is what I felt made the show unique: 
It is a harem anime but unlike I lot of them the main character is not two-timing any girls and he actually picks one for each arc. You will see 4 (technically 5 in the chibi skits at the end) girls get pursued by Haruka and each only one at a time. You getto learn about each girl and the pattern is that Haruka is kind and helps them overcome some problem or trauma and after that they get into a relationship and have sex. 


That's basically the plot and though on occasion the sex seems to accentuate the story a bit (like Akira) it felt a bit out of place and rushed and more for fanservice. The one case where the sex affects the story a LOT is in the last two arcs where Haruka starts to realize he is attracted to his sister--more on that later. 


The situations each girl is in and some of the problems he helps them through are unique and some of them, like akira, I found particularly heart-touching. After coming to the conclusion of each arc with each girl it appears to reset to a sort of "save point" in the story prior giving Haruka a chance to make a different choice and learn about a different girl. This is why I said it resembles a dating simulator animated. I thought this was rather clever and enjoyed it more then the typical harem style. 


Story: 5/10


There isn't a lot of character development because there isn't a lot of episodes devoted to each girl but I was satisfied with the way I got to learn about each person and watch them both change as they interacted with Haruka. They originally, as is often the case, start as somewhat cliched character stereotypes but you get to see them be developed more and feel a greater depth behind each character then is often the case, especially in short anime. 


Character Development: 6/10


The art was very pretty. I found the style very appealing and the music choices accentuated the animation well. I watched subtitled so I can't say much about the voice-actors not speaking native Japanese myself. 


Art: 8/10


So...on the incest: 

The last girl is Haruka's sister Sora, as pretty much everyone should know from any review on here. 

It was an interesting final story that added some dimension to them but, unlike a lot of viewers I didn't find it particularly profound and it made me more worried for them. A lot of viewers loved the idea of forbidden love and said this anime was great for raising questions and challenging society. I tend to think they are wrong, but not because society says so. There are some really good reasons why I didn't think the anime developed this as well as they could have. Just raising a touchy subject and simplifying it doesn't make the anime "great". (my thoughts here will be long so skip if you want)


The anime is trying to make the viewer think about societal pressures and if they are arbitrary. If Haruka loves his sister is a sexual relationship ok? How much is? Is loving someone enough to justify resisting society on this issue? It tries very hard to set this up as a situation where Haruka feels powerless in the face of feelings and society is coming between them. But...the anime robs the situation of its complexity by failing to emphasize the choices each character makes and the possible forms of love. And thus makes a fundamental mistake about the nature of it. It also robs the situation of its potential problems by presenting a "happily ever after" choice. Basically Sora and Haruka can move away and go incognito and that's that. 


First off, "lust" is not "love", something many people have difficulty recognizing the difference between. I can want to have sex with someone but not love them and want to spend my life with them. Basing a relationship solely on sexual attraction is asking to fail. Similarly, you don't need sexuality to have a good relationship. What matters is the growing intimacy between two people and how they grow to understand and look out for each other. This is what holds relationships together and should be looked for primarily when thinking about making a long-term relationship choice. Sex is the worst glue for a relationship ever, and yet the sister, Sora only seems happy with a physical relationship with her brother? And angry when he is kind and does things for her, makes time for her, but doesn't have sex with her and kiss her? It seems an arbitrary scenario. 


When it comes down to it, there are way more choices involved here then the anime makes you think. Being sexually attracted to someone is not love as we can clearly see Haruka could have chosen any of the girls (and does in other arcs). Love is usually not a powerful emotion that you are doomed to follow but fundamentally has choices and complexity. 


But the anime doesn't explore this open avenue at all. it basically just shows Haruka realizing he is sexually attracted to his sister after seeing her masturbating and jumping straight to "move to another city and live our life together to escape persecution and our family". Despite the fact that it is clear Sora is not the only person he is attracted too. What Haruka wants is a relationship with his sister. When that is threatened (mainly by Sora's own feelings but also by the potential breakup of them by family members after their parents death) he chooses her. But I don't see why the siblings couldn't insist to their relatives they stay together and expressed that love in a non-sexual way. It felt like a forced plot device. Heck, they could have even continued to live together. It made sense because his sister has health problems and he could keep taking care of her. But the anime made it this "all or nothing" sort of scenario. 


Beyond this, I think the focus on physical relationship actually has a very high chance of hurting or destroying their relationship in the long run. Imagine how awkward it will be if this is not a happily ever after story and later one of them wants to explore other relationships again? By making this choice they are setting themselves up for an awkward estrangement in the future made all the more awkward by the fact that they are siblings. Once they've chosen to have sex and be involved in this way, they can never go back to the innocent love of "just being siblings". If something happens and they break up they will be unable to be there for each other in the same way due to this past, losing forever the chance to support each other as just sister/brother. This is made even sadder by the fact that their parents are dead and they have no other family they are close too. At this time after the loss of their parents they both need close family and romantic relationships. They will be healthier with both imho. And it is sad to me to see them rolled into one with the future possibility that they could lose both. I would have loved to see this developed or even considered but it isn't. 


TL;DR: I think the anime made the characters seem powerless and two-dimensional by making it seem like they "had no choice" and were "victims" when they really had all the choices. It is a classic "depowering" under the guise of "romance" and something I really don't like seeing. They also failed to address the complex issues of these choices such as the fact that by choosing a sexual relationship the siblings are most likely sacrificing their relationship ever being innocent love again.

MAY CONTAIN MINOR SPOILERS
I am going to preface this review by saying that this ecchi does cover a taboo in it, and that while from a personal perspective I have no issue with this, from a logical perspective there is issues with it, and it's most likely true that most people will find some issue with, or be repulsed by, the taboo in this show. In spite of this, I do feel that this is worth a watch. I will be covering the taboo later in the review as it could be considered a minor spoiler.
Let's start with the aspect of this that I foundthe best; the sound.

It's rare for me to pay much attention to soundtracks, and when I do it's because  they contain songs that I know and love, like the Guardians of the Galaxy movies, or because they make me feel the emotional impact of scenes and interactions, and add what could almost be considered non-verbal story-telling.

Yosuga no Sora falls under the latter. The music in this is amazing, matching up with each and every scene almost flawlessly. The fact that I felt like crying and laughing in various points was made possible by the music. There were scenes where the music was the only real sound there, and those scenes conveyed so much emotion. The one that sticks out the most was one of the sex scenes, which I found to be the most tasteful of them all, where they interchanged it and another scene showing great character development without any speech. That's truly impressive. 

The voice acting was also very well done, and I felt the emotions that were in them. There's not much more to say than that, I'm not really someone who pays much mind to this.

I'm speaking a lot about the emotions, and how I felt them through the music and the acting. I feel that I need to explain this by saying that I'm not someone who finds much emotional impact in things, especially in romances, which makes this somewhat unique for me. Because of the emotions, the music that makes perfect sense for each and every scene, and the amazingly done voice acting, I rate this category 10/10


Now let's talk about the art. Fuck me the art is great. The backdrops are simple, but I feel that it was a good choice to keep the scenery simple to keep the focus on the main aspect of the series; The characters. The characters art in this was really well done, and from what I've seen from other reviews, this is important considering its visual novel source. I found everything pleasing to look at, not just the curves. I really felt the emotions that the characters were going through when I looked at their faces, which were enhanced further by the voice acting and music. The sex scenes were done tastefully, and the style and frequency of them was mostly due to the source material. I did find some dilemma in the fact that the female characters were all under 18, and we see breasts from them, however I decided that due to the look and mature feel of them, as well as my views that breasts being seen as sexual is a bit stupid, I can overlook this aspect. Laws in Australia (Where I live) state that basically if the characters are 20 but look 10, then it can be considered child pornography, or if they are under 16 (Like most of these characters) but look far more mature than that then things get iffy. Sorry for that aside, but I do feel that it was necessary to mention.

Overall, I feel that the art and animations were a large part of why I enjoyed it. Easy 10/10 for me.


It was somewhat tricky to decide which to tackle first out of characters and story, and after some thought I've decided to go with story.

For the most part, the story is pretty good. I found it somewhat confusing at first, but after reading a few comments on this I managed a good understanding of how it works. The short of it is, Yosuga no Sora began as a visual novel wherein the player has the ability to romance various heroines, leading to a sex scene etc. The anime follows this idea, and at the end of each arc, returns to a previous point in the story and goes "Well what if this character showed up at this spot rather than this character" and other things along that line. I personally found this to be really effective, and a very interesting way to transfer that kind of source material into a series like this. It did have some downsides, however. I was left wanting more for the stories of each of the heroines, and felt somewhat unsatisfied by this. On the other side, they managed to tell the stories of each character extremely well in the few episodes that were assigned to each. That is truly an impressive feat, and kept me hooked. The downside was enough for me to bring down the score from an easy 10/10 to an 8/10. 


And now we get the characters.

Each character is multi-layered and unique. I know that there are terms for their types, but I do not know them, and find them annoying when reading reviews and conversations about things. As such, I will be using none of them.

For me, the characters were relatable, to an extent. They all struggled with something on their conscience or with other aspects of their life, and they all dealt with their problems in their own ways. The one that stuck out most for me was one of the heroines who felt she had wronged the main character, and was constantly beating herself up about it (Metaphorically, not literally). There was also twincest in here, which I personally have no issue with, but biologically speaking, I do have issues with. I feel the need to mention here that Sigmund Freud had theories that support the idea that we are attracted to our siblings and parents, and seek out romantic/sexual partners that remind us of them. I feel that this arc was the most interesting of all of them, showing a conflict of morality versus emotion versus societal views. It was interesting, and tackled well. It is this taboo that I feel is the culprit of the marring of some reviews. I also understand why it would put people off it.

For the same reason as the story, characters get an 8/10


Overall, I enjoyed this a lot, and will be definitely re-watching it in the future. 10/10 for enjoyment. The average of the scores is a 9/10, rounded to the nearest whole number. I do this as I feel that the average is the best way to give an overall score for a review.

So, I kinda liked and disliked this anime. It isn't your typical ecchi and harem anime. The MC isn't a dunce who can't make up his mind. Instead, it's more a straightforward ecchi anime. The romances develop between the characters through different scenarios. For example, after one romance is concluded, a fresh romance starts from what I'd call a "checkpoint". There aren't multiple romances at once. 
The romance stories of the first two romances was very well developed to me. However, towards the remainder of the series, it really threw me off. That said, let's just say that Sora has a very large big brothercomplex. 


The art style is great and the sound is amazing. The characters could've had more development though. I really wish that they had extended the two romances at the beginning.

I watched this 7 years ago and I rewatched it today because I remembered this show made a slight impression on me and I couldn't figure out why I assigned such a low rating for this show when I returned to my MAL page. 
Yosuga no Sora explores the very touchy subject of incest, it a taboo subject and would probably turn anyone away, let alone watch an anime about it. But if you have the patience and open mind to give this a try, you'll be pleasantly surprised with what the show has to offer. If anything, I think the only flaw with thisshow was the excessive lewd scenes and they don't address the incest stuff until the very end.


Anyways the story is about a fraternal twin Haru (the guy) and Sora (the girl) returning to the village they grew up in and getting used to school life. The story is broken up into a few arcs, each arc is focused on a separate girl in the village who has a crush on Haru. Each arc gives you more insight about the girls, the town they live in, Haru and Sora's past, and of course the relationship between Haru and Sora through the other girls' perspective. It's somewhat nonchalant and layback, and it was the slice of life aspect that made me engaged with the story.


The most interesting character is definitely Sora who is extremely a fragile mentally and physically character. She is spoiled, complains a lot, and gets easily jealous. But you can't fault her or hate her because the writing is very good at showing how and why she acts like this. So instead of hate, you actually sympathize with her. Her brother Haru is pretty much just an average main character of a harem, but he does have some life to his characte. He isn't perfect (other than his looks) and get easily tempted. The other girls in the show are all archetype, they don't serve much purpose other than a plot device for either showing us the environment or initiate the twin's relationship. 


The visuals are okay from what I remembered, but the animation was incredible for this genre. There were a few cinematic scenes that made me go "wow, I am going to remember this". There was also a lot of effort put into the lewd scenes, let's just say those scenes were especially  "energetic"....


Finally the best part about this show and I think what made the show was the OST. It's also an OST they play every episode in different forms in different situations. It brings out different emotions in you, it can feel calm, mysterious, happy, exciting, mellow, dearing, and most definitely nostalgic. 


This is an anime is great if you want to explore a little and are not afraid of the subject. I just wish they cut down on the lewd stuff

Nachvollziehen kann ich dabei seine Ansicht schon, würde vermutlich genau sohandeln.

There are so many things which are wrong about so many of the relationships in this anime. It basically reads like a high school student's sexual fantasies put into animation. So depending on what you're wanting to get out of this the scoring differs. For a romance it gets a 6, but for a watch-at-midnight-by-yourself anime it's more like a 7.5 because they are fairly gratuitous with showing off body parts and uh, physical recreation.
There is a semi-decent storyline compared to other animes of this sort for the different story arcs, but because each one is so short there's pretty much no feels for anyof the characters. The way they do the transitions between each story arc is quite good though with same scene-different ending though. 


I watched the first arc in full but then basically just skipped to the bits with the action. One thing which really annoyed me though was how frequently they get all the girls naked in this but have Haruka (the male lead) still with all his clothes on. Kinda sexist. And my goodness, how they exaggerate the size of every female's breasts. Character art design almost certainly done by a male.


The OP and EN themes are really beautiful though.

Let's get this out of the way now, if you're uncomfortable with watching a show with nudity and graphic sexual situations, get used to it, because Yosuga no Sora is a hidden masterpiece.
Every aspect of this show is amazing. Each story arc gives us a short, yet emotional tale of the main characters relationship with a different girl each arc, and they are some of the most mind blowing stories I've ever had the privilege to witness. The arcs last just long enough, and all provide a unique scenario for the arcs main girl and the main character to overcome.
Addressing the erotic content, Yosuga noSora has a lot. Sometimes it serves a purpose to the story or comedy, and other times it's gratuitous and not really necessary, and in these times it often feels silly to watch. In spite of this, it's not enough to diminish the quality by even a point, because the pros outweigh the cons just that much. When the erotic content is used properly, it provides some of the most romantic scenes I've ever seen.


Using captivating music and animation, Yosuga no Sora is still has one of the most pleasing aesthetics of any anime. One thing that really stands out to me is the lighting. Things as simple as a dim lit bedroom, beams of a sunset cascading through the gaps in the trees in the forest, or the sudden crash of lightning on a dark and rainy night. Many fans of Yosuga no Sora will praise how the show has this very calm, and relaxed fell to it. It's animation and music help you to drift away into the magically normal world of Yosuga no Sora, and immerse you deeper within it, and it makes the story all that more filled with life.


Yosuga no Sora also poses many controversial moral questions, that most shows wouldn't have nearly enough guts to tackle. It brings up the subject of incest, and gives us a new viewpoint on the subject by putting us in the characters shoes, and does so without ever feeling preachy or shoving it down our throats. It gives an intentionally complicated view on the matter, because it's very rare that things are clear cut black and white.


Overall, Yosuga no Sora is a masterpiece, that unfortunately, to many people shy away from because of the erotic content and the subject of incest. If I could say anything to these people, I would ask them to bear with it, because when it comes down to it, it's a shame that anyone who holds a appreciation for stories should miss out on such an amazing one.

Yosuga no Sora is about twin brother and sister, Haruka and Sora moving to their grandparents countryside home after they orphaned. The series follows four separate storylines where you see Haruka forming romantic relationships with four separate girls. Three of the stories are sweet for the most part while the fourth made me very uncomfortable. The series is filled with a lot of softcore hentai and although that's not my cup of tea, it kind of helped appreciate the romance in each relationship and in two of the relationships even fueled the storyline to progress in a more dramatic way. Understanding that these are fourdifferent stories involving the same characters is pretty key to watching the series. Now I said before three of the stories are sweet for the most part while the fourth is rather uncomfortable. The reason it is uncomfortable (and you should catch this by the end of episode 1) is because the fourth story involves an incestuous relationship between Haruka and Sora. Now I understand you can't help who you fall in love with and all but I just can't get past the fact that these two are siblings. Maybe I'm ignorant but that's just how I feel. Incest and softcore henati aside, the relationships are indeed sweet and the characters are all very diverse, each one dealing with their own personal demons and Haruka seems to be the only person who can put a smile on their faces. The series is rather different from anything I've seen, nothing groundbreaking but if sweet romance, softcore hentai and incest is your thing then this would be the perfect series for you.

Like other people here, it was in my endeavors to find some decent anime with nudity (nudity makes all art more fun, as long as it's quality) that I stumbled upon this show.
It starts off pretty rough, with all this slice-of-life drama and not-at-all interesting initial plot setup sliced up with occasionally grossly pervy panty shots and other such creepshot breast-in-shirt ogling or whatever. I'm really not against pervy stuff, look into my anime history (I started watching anime with the intent to find anime sex and boobs for my partner), it's just the intent that matters to me, I guess. Hentai is honest. HighSchool DxD is honest with itself--the main character is a boob-obsessed perv. Queen's Blade feels honest too--it wants to be a show about "strong" females that just happen to keep chopping each other's tops off. This felt dishonest, because it pretends to be some sort of romance, but does all these creepy little things along the way that feel way more voyeuristic, in a bad way, than all of that other blatant ecchi stuff.


But, I decided to persevere, and there's definitely a bit of a shift as soon as the Nao arc starts -- the show started to engage me as an OK romance, with boobs (which is what I was looking for in the first place). 


Then the show surprised me and engaged me even further with the final arc. Haru and Sora are disgusting, and I expected to only be more and more grossed out by the show's pervy ideals in relation to those relations, but I gotta say, the show handles that salacious material quite well, with some really great, shocking, dramatic moments--particularly those endings! 


I still can't help but feel like this is still exploitative and it creeps me out thinking someone wrote this only to be able to draw up their incestuous fantasies, but in the Nao arc and the final arc I kept thinking to myself that this kind of sexuality was what I was looking for -- natural and not afraid to show sex or nudity.


One of my biggest issues with all these ecchi shows is the noxious fan ideals of keeping their anime goddesses pure and virginal. I gotta at least give this one credit for (at least in the second half) having sex scenes that felt like they had purpose, or were given some sort of narrative weight or IDK-- and not being afraid of sexuality. Like all of the basement nerds all those Heaven's Lost Property type trash shows are about.


I'm getting way off base here-- anyway, this is... an interesting show. I wouldn't really recommend it. But you could do way worse.

Tl;dr: this series' greatness depends on your own personal viewpoint. If you're a person that is strictly influenced by the moral of this world regarding incest, then I suggest to watch only until episode 9ish or something and drop it, or even not to consider watching it at all.
But if you are an open minded person that would actually think more deeply and wouldn't jump onto a typical prejudice and disgust, then you're more than welcome to try this.
I would like to say that I am reviewing this based on a neutral viewpoint, hence the morality of this series will not affect how good orbad this series is. And also in each arc of this series there will be a bit H scene so do consider this too when wanting to watch this.


Yosuga no Sora, despite being a rare type of series, is one of the interesting series I had ever watch. Even after rewatching this after four years or so, it didn't let me down. The storyline consist of a few different arcs such as a vn would be, because this series is actually an adaptation of the vn. There are four arcs in this series, and the last arc is the true ending. After a route have finished, the next episode retracts to an event where the  main protagonist would choose a different route than the first route.


Each storyline has its own meaningful story and is quite emotional. The theme of this series is a really deep and serious one and the soundtrack also seems to fit on this. The soundtracks are emotional and always matches with the situation of the story. Furthermore, all of the soundtracks are great to hear and it is also one of the plus points on why I liked this series. However, despite having a good story the pacing is faster than the usual ones that it felt somewhat rushed. This might be because they had to compress four different story onto a 12 episode long anime, which is one of its shortcoming. Another one would be that even though having a good introduction and character development for its side character, the main character itself, Sora and Haru didn't really seem to get developed deeper. Whilst the first three arc had its own unique conflict and resolution, Sora's arc only had an internal conflict between them and the resolution of it felt dull. Nevertheless, this series is great and not disappointing. The reactions and actions are fairly realistic especially how they describe the internal conflict of the last arc, since that matter itself is a complex one.


For the conflict of the moralism, as I said in the tldr note, those who are strictly influenced by the morals of this world regarding incest, then I suggest to watch it only until episode 9ish and stop there. Or maybe even not to consider watching this. The reason why I said this is because the anime itself isn't that bad and I don't want to say that it is bad just because of the last arc of incest.

From episode 1 to 9, the first until the third arc could still be digested rationally. But, the episode after that might not be easily digested if you have a strict viewpoint and if you were to force yourself to watch it, you might find it destroying the whole image of the story. However, if you are a very open minded person (like me) that is willing to think more deeply on things and wouln't throw the typical prejudice and disgust, then digesting the last arc would not be too much of a problem.


Overall, this series is (really) enjoyable for me and I would recommend to watch this.

Ok, I've finished watching the anime and I wanted to say that if you like Harem-kind of anime then you should watch it. This is just a random anime that I've picked, I don't know what kind of anime it was but when I watched the first episode and saw the main male protagonist being called 'cute', and saw two other hot chicks blushed just by looking at the guy's face showing interest then yeah... this is definitely a harem anime.
Story 6/10 Basically, The story is like playing an eroge(I haven't played one yet but I knew how the game works) since the game ISbased from an eroge. The first two episode is just a mere introduction, the 3rd episode is where the eroge-like part kicks in. The main character is going to talked to the girl and soon sleeps with them. That part is predictable, he WILL have sex with every female characters(except for one). This is truly a romance anime but with the softcore hentai part ruins it.


Art 9/10 I like the art, it's decent, not too ugly nor too perfect. 


Sound 5/10 I gave it a 5? well, I don't pretty much care about the sounds. It just sounded the same to me just like any other anime. Though there are certain anime that has such an annoying voice but not this one.




Character 8/10 Every character has there own personality's well done. Some characters you just can't predict what they are going to do next, the characters are mostly females with two males, one being the hero of the anime. The female characters will show signs of interest to the male protagonist.


Enjoyment 10/10 I gave it a 10 not because of the softcore hentai scenes, it's censored anyway -.-". I like it because of the good endings, some anime have bad endings that just leave you depressed and angry, not satisfied with how it should have ended. This anime, well... every girl received their love by this one guy(again, except for one). Though this is like an eroge, like which girl you're going to choose? which route you're going to start with. The female character's story is told one at a time. You could say it's like an alternative ending for the anime where this one guy will love this one girl and there love life goes on... the end. Then the next episode starts but now, the guy will be with the other female characters and their love story will be told....


Overall, I gave it a very good 8. You should watch this aniime if you like harem romance anime.

Yosuga no Sora is simply one of the most unique anime's i have watched
When i began the series, i had little to no idea as to what i was getting myself into, i was expecting your typical slice of life romance anime. But interestingly it took a turn for the eechi side, which completely blew my socks off.
Yes, you guessed it, THIS ANIME HAS SEX IN IT, however this does contribute to plot and character development and your able to see the effect it has on each girl afterwards. So it simply isn't a pointless hentai that is only good to jack off to.
 Theanime is based off a visual novel, so every girl has their own arc and their own version of the story. However each arc has no correlation to each other until you get to the final one. In each arc (which would be every 2 episodes) you see the story from a different perspective with multiple changes, although the one aspect that never changes in all these arcs is the main character


The main Character Haruka is simply a guy who is a little too perfect. With a chill personality and an overpowering charisma level he is basically responsible for all the arcs in the anime by peeking the interests of the girls around him. But this is only the surface of his character, in reality he is character of multiple imperfections who is often weak and indecisive. His inability to cope with certain scenarios is what causes the abrupt swings in the flow of the storyline, and as a result not the best result is achieved at the end of every arc


Sora is the main character's little sister who you simply cannot come to hate . She is troubled and distressed and has spent alot of time in hospital due to her health, but within this time she developed a certain "love" for her brother Haruka. Sora would do anything to not have her brother taken away from her by any other girl, this would be to the point in which you could potentially call her yandere. However as the anime progresses you begin to see the insecurites within Sora change her and her mentality which then takes this anime down the road of incest where things start to get to interesting (im not gonna spoil anything)


And now for the girls. At first they seem quite ordinary and boring but in their arcs you come to see that every character has a certain amount of depth and imperfections to them. they all bring something to the table and control the ebb and flow of the plot and the main character. I personally liked Kazuha (the class president) who gives off a "commanding Onee chan" vibe despite being a kind hearted girl who cares for everyone. Other girls such as Akira (the shrine maiden) come off as the typical carefree, happy maiden who always has a smile on her face, however deep down she is extremely emotional and has her own set of problems to deal with. 


So the characters themselves are quite versetile and likeable, i would give them a 8


Now for storyline. The Slice of life aspect of Yosuga no Sora keeps the plot steady and there are no inconsistencies within time or setting in the anime. However the anime does opt to go for the same layout every arc. The girl gets introduced to the MC, there are several encounters and a potential date on the line and then at the very end Haruka gets down to business with the girl in bed. Even though it is portrayed in every arc differently, it is still quite bland since your expecting the same thing every arc. At times I was more hyped for the soft core porn rather than i was for the story. Many of the girls also seemed less likable in their own arcs (until you got see the oppai) but the anime was made so that the personalities could be more believable. But each girl made Yosuga no Sora the unique anime it is with its ups and downs. 


 In the end the storyline was quite mediocre and i can only give it a 6


One of the things i like the most about this anime was the art style. The Art style was crisp and smooth and quite easily one of the best i have seen. the nature and characters were all done well and given their own personality. Also the eechi scenes were quite on point and detailed. At the end of every episode there is a section done is Chibi art which i am also quite fond of. Seeing the characters with massive heads and unproportionate bodies was quite hilarious. I would give the Art style and easy solid 8


The sound in this anime was also done really well. The voice acting was not sloppy and done well, I can easily say it was better than many of the mainstream animes out there. the background music and OST was also crisp and appropriate and i felt as if though it synced really well with the anime. The sound was of exceptional quality a 9 from me


Overall i really like Yosuga no Sora, It was quite different from what i expected in a good way and i was able to see things in a different manner after watching this. For someone like myself who watches anime merely for good plot character development i enjoyed Yosuga no Sora thoroughly and would give it a 7 Overall
